facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated July 12, 1962 of the Bombay High Court, Nagpur Bench in appeal No. 16 of 1960 under the Letters Patent.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated July 12, 1962 of the Bombay High Court, Nagpur Bench in appeal No. 16 of 1960 under the Letters Patent.

facts.text: Respondents were members of a Co-operative Housing Society and had created a mortgage on their property in favour of the society.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents were members of a Co-operative Housing Society and had created a mortgage on their property in favour of the society.

facts.text: Amount due under the mortgage was not paid, matter referred to the Registrar, Co-operative Societies.

anchor.surface_text: As the amount due under the mortgage was number paid, the matter was referred to the Registrar, Co-operative Societies,

facts.text: Registrar made an order dated May 1, 1957 directing respondents to pay Rs. 9,000 and odd plus interest at Rs. 12 per cent per annum from August 1, 1953 till satisfaction.

anchor.surface_text: and he made an order dated May 1, 1957 that the respondents should pay a sum of Rs. 9,000 and odd and interest at Rs. 12 per cent per annum from August 1, 1953 till satisfaction of the debt due to the Society.

facts.text: Registrar directed that if amount not paid in cash, property would be sold in satisfaction, and society could proceed for balance if not realised.

anchor.surface_text: The Registrar further directed that if the amount was number paid in cash to the society, the property mentioned in his order would be sold in satisfaction of the amount. The order also provided that in case the amount due was number realised from the sale of the property, the society would have the right to proceed against the respondents for the balance.

facts.text: Amount was not paid as directed.

anchor.surface_text: The amount was number paid as directed in the order.

facts.text: Application made to civil court for recovery of amount under Registrar's order, which amounted to a decree.

anchor.surface_text: Consequently an application was made to the civil companyrt as provided by law for recovery of the amount under the order of the Registrar which amounted to a decree.

facts.text: Property brought to sale, sale held on April 7, 1958, appellant highest bidder, sale concluded in his favour.

anchor.surface_text: In companysequence the property on which charge was created by the order of the Registrar was brought to sale. The sale was held on April 7, 1958 and the appellant being the highest bidder, the sale was companycluded in his favour.

facts.text: Application made on May 3, 1958 under O. XXI r. 90 of the Code of Civil Procedure.

anchor.surface_text: As an application had been made on May 3, 1958 under O. XXI r. 90 of the Code of Civil Procedure,

facts.text: Proceedings under O. XXI r. 90 went on up to October 7, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: the sale companyld number be companyfirmed till that application was disposed of. Proceedings under O. XXI rule 90 seem to have gone on upto October 7, 1958.

facts.text: On October 7, 1958, one of the respondents gave evidence as witness, then before society's evidence, respondents requested one month's time to deposit decretal amount plus auction-purchaser's commission, prepared to withdraw r.90 application.

anchor.surface_text: On that day it appears that one of the respondents gave evidence as a witness. Thereafter it was the turn of the Society decree-holder to give evidence. But before the evidence of the society began, it appears that respondents requested for one months time to deposit the decretal amount along with the auction- purchasers companymission.

facts.text: Society and auction-purchaser had no objection to time being allowed; executing court granted time till November 21, 1958 to deposit entire amount plus commission.

anchor.surface_text: They also appear to have stated that in that event they were prepared to withdraw their application under O. XXI r. 90. The society as well as the auction-purchaser had numberobjection to time being allowed. The executing companyrt therefore granted time to the respondents till November 21, 1958 to deposit the entire decretal amount along with the auction-purchasers companymission.

facts.text: Application under O. XXI r. 90 dismissed as withdrawn with no order as to costs on October 7, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: After time was thus allowed with companysent of the parties, the application under O. XXI r. 90 was dismissed as withdrawn with numberorder as to companyts.

facts.text: On November 20, 1958, respondents made application referring to October 7 order, stating November 21 holiday, prayed for one day time to deposit on November 22.

anchor.surface_text: On November 20, 1958, an application was made by he respondents in which they referred to what had been ordered on October 7, 1958. They further stated that November 21, 1958 was a holiday and it was number possible to deposit the amount on that day though they were prepared to do so.

facts.text: No order passed on November 20, 1958 application, though endorsed as filed that day.

anchor.surface_text: They companysequently prayed for time for one day so that the deposit might be made on November 22, 1958. No order was passed on this application on November 20, 1958 though it bears an endorsement of the executing companyrt to the effect that it had been filed on November 20, 1958.

facts.text: November 21, 1958 was a holiday.

anchor.surface_text: November 21, 1958 being a holiday

facts.text: On November 22, 1958, court noted no amount deposited; counsel for respondents prayed for fortnight time extension; opposed by society and auction-purchaser.

anchor.surface_text: it appears that the matter came before the executing companyrt on November 22. On that day the companyrt numbered that numberamount had been deposited. The order-sheet also shows that companynsel for the respondents prayed for time for a fortnight. The society decree-holder as well as the auction-purchaser  appellant  opposed the prayer for extension of time.

facts.text: Executing court held it could not extend time given under agreement of parties, rejected prayer, confirmed sale under O. XXI r. 92 as r.90 app dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The executing companyrt held that as the society decree-holder and the auction-purchaser were number willing to extend time the companyrt companyld number extend time which had been given under an agreement of the parties by way of companypromise. The companyrt therefore rejected the prayer for extension of time and thereafter companyfirmed the sale as required by 0 XXI r. 92

facts.text: Respondents appealed to District Judge; appeal allowed, executing court order set aside, case remitted to decide extension application on merits.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents went in appeal to the District Judge. He held that the companyrt had always the power whether under S. 148 of the Code of Civil Procedure or otherwise, to postpone passing of orders companyfirming sale of immovable properties. ... The appeal was therefore allowed, the order of the executing companyrt set aside and the case remitted to. the executing companyrt

facts.text: Appellant filed second appeal to High Court; Single Judge held O. XXXIV r.5 not apply, sale rightly confirmed, s.148 not invocable, allowed appeal, restored executing court order.

anchor.surface_text: There was then a second appeal by the appellant to the High Court. ... The learned Single Judge seems to have held that O. XXXIV r. 5 did number apply. He further held that in view. of the provisions of O. XXI r. 92, the sale was rightly companyfirmed and s. 148 of the Code of Civil Procedure companyld number under the circumstances be invoked. The appeal therefore was allowed

facts.text: Respondents filed Letters Patent Appeal; Division Bench held O. XXXIV r.5 applies, allowed appeal, set aside Single Judge order, restored District Judge order, set aside confirmation on Nov 22, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: Then there was a Letters Patent Appeal by the respondents. The Division Bench appears to have held that O. XXXIV r. 5 would apply in a case of this kind. ... It appears that as the respondents had deposited some money after the order of the District Judge in appeal, the Letters Patent Bench allowed the appeal, set aside the order of the learned Single Judge and restored the order of the District Judge and further set aside the order of companyfirmation made by the executing companyrt on November 22, 1958.

facts.text: High Court refused leave to appeal to Supreme Court; appellant obtained special leave.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court having refused leave to appeal, the appellant obtained special leave from this Court, and that is how the matter has companye before us.

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed appellant's appeal, set aside Letters Patent Bench and District Judge orders, restored executing court order dated November 22, 1958 confirming sale in favour of appellant.

anchor.surface_text: We, allow the appeal, set aside the order of the Letters Patent Bench and of the District Judge and restore that of the executing companyrt dated November 22, 1958. It follows that the sale stood companyfirmed in favour of the appellant on November 22, 1958.

facts.text: Respondents deposited some money after District Judge order, in 1959, not before confirmation on Nov 22, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: It may be added that this deposit was number made before the companyfirmation 69 9 of sale on November 22, 1958 but long afterwards in 1959.

facts.text: No amount deposited on November 20, 1958 or November 22, 1958 before confirmation.

anchor.surface_text: No order was passed on that date, but it is remarkable that numbermoney was deposited on November 20, 1958. When the matter came up before the companyrt on November 22, 1958 numbermoney was deposited even on that day.

facts.text: Time till November 21, 1958 granted by consent of parties on October 7, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: Obviously the basis of the companypromise was that the respondents withdrew their application under O. XXI r. 90 while the decree-holder society and the auction-purchaser appellant agreed that time might be given to deposit the amount up to November 21, 1958.

facts.text: District Judge noted no written application on November 22, 1958, only oral prayer.

anchor.surface_text: It may be mentioned that though the District Judge said in the order that the application presented on November 22, 1958 for granting further time would be disposed of after hearing parties and companysidering the merits of the case, there was in fact numberwritten application on November 22, 1958 and there was only an oral prayer.

issues.text: whether the executing court was right in the view that it could not extend time which had been given by consent of parties on October7, 1958

anchor.surface_text: The High Court having refused leave to appeal, the appellant obtained special leave from this Court, and that is how the matter has come before us. The principal question that arises for decision in this case is whether the executing court was right in the view that it could not extend time which had been given by consent of parties on October7, 1958.

arguments.claim: O. XXXIV r. 5 recognises right to deposit before confirmation but does not give court power to extend time or postpone confirmation

anchor.surface_text: Though O. XXXIV r. 5 (1) recognises the right of the judgment-debtor to pay the decretal amount in an execution relating to a mortgage decree for sale at any time before, the confirmation of sale, that in our opinion does not mean that be said rule gives power to the court to extend time for payment on an application made by the judgment-debtor. There is no provision in O. XXXIV r. 5 (1) like that contained in O. XXXIV r. 4 (2) to extend time for payment after the final decree is passed in a mortgage suit.

arguments.claim: Court has no power to indefinitely postpone confirmation under O. XXI r. 92 to accommodate judgment-debtor

anchor.surface_text: The observation of the District Judge that the court has always the power to postpone passing orders confirming sale of immovable property is in our view incorrect, in the face of the provisions contained in O. XXI r. 92 (1). That provision makes it absolutely clear that if no application is made under r. 89, r. 90 or r. 91 or where such application is made and disallowed, the court has to make an order confirming the sale and thereupon the sale becomes absolute. It is not open to the court to go on fixing date after date and postponing confirmation of sale merely to accommodate a judgment-debtor.

arguments.claim: O. XXXIV r. 5 and O. XXI r. 92 must be read harmoniously: deposit permitted before confirmation, but confirmation mandatory under r92 unless deposit made

anchor.surface_text: We have to interpret O. XXXIV r. 5 and O. XXI r. 92 harmoniously and on a harmonious interpretation of the two provisions it is clear that though the mortgagor has the right to deposit the amount due at any time before confirmation of sale, there is no question of his being granted time under O. XXXIV r. 5 and if the provisions of O. XXI r. 92 (1) apply the sale must be confirmed unless before the confirmation the mortgagor judgment-debtor has deposited the amount as permitted by O. XXXIV r. 5.

arguments.claim: Once conditions of O. XXI r. 92(1) satisfied, court must confirm sale

anchor.surface_text: We may in this connection refer to the decision of this Court in Janak Rai v. Gurdial Singh, where it has been laid down that once the conditions of O. XXI r. 92 (1) are complied with, the executing court must confirm the sale.

arguments.claim: Time extension on Oct 7 was by consent of parties as basis for withdrawal of O XXI r90 application

anchor.surface_text: It is obvious from the order-sheet of October 7, 1958 that an oral compromise was arrived at between the parties in court on that day. By that compromise time was granted to the respondents to deposit the entire amount due to the decree-holder and the auction-purchaser by November 21, 1958. Obviously the basis of the compromise was that the respondents withdrew their application under O. XXI r. 90 while the decree-holder society and the auction-purchaser appellant agreed that time might be given to deposit the amount up to November 21, 1958.

holdings.text: The executing court was right in holding that it could not extend the time granted by consent of parties on October 7, 1958, as Section 148 CPC does not apply to such consent-based time extensions, and the sale confirmation under O. XXI r. 92 was proper.

anchor.surface_text: We are of the view that in the circumstances it was number open to the executing companyrt to extend time without companysent of parties for time between October 7, 1958 to November 21, 1958 was granted by companysent of parties. Section 148 of the Code Civil Procedure would number apply in these circumstances, and the executing companyrt was right in holding that it companyld number extend time. Thereafter it rightly the sale as required under O. XXI r. 92

holdings.reasoning_summary: Time fixed by oral compromise between parties; court cannot unilaterally extend without consent; O.XXI r.92 mandates confirmation post r.90 dismissal without deposit.

holdings.text: O. XXXIV r. 5 recognises mortgagor's right to deposit before confirmation of sale but confers no power on court to extend time for deposit or postpone confirmation.

anchor.surface_text: Though O. XXXIV r. 5 (1) recognises the right of the judgment-debtor to pay the decretal amount in an execution relating to a mortgage decree for sale at any time before, the companyfirmation of sale, that in our opinion does number mean that be said rule gives power to the companyrt to extend time for payment on an application made by the judgment-debtor. There is- numberprovision in O. XXXIV r. 5 1 like that contained in O. XXXIV r. 4 2 to extend time for payment after the final decree is passed in a mortgage suit.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation distinguishes from O.XXXIV r.4(2); rule only permits deposit, no extension provision unlike mortgage suit final decree.

holdings.text: Court has no power under S. 148 CPC or otherwise to indefinitely postpone confirmation of sale under O. XXI r. 92 merely to accommodate judgment-debtor.

anchor.surface_text: The observation of the District Judge that the companyrt has always the power to postpone passing orders companyfirming sale of immovable property is in our view incorrect, in the face of the provisions companytained in O. XXI r. 92 (1). That provision makes it absolutely clear that if numberapplication is made under r. 89, r. 90 or r. 91 or where such application is made and disallowed, the companyrt has to make an order companyfirming the sale and thereupon the ,ale becomes absolute.

holdings.reasoning_summary: O.XXI r.92(1) mandatory; prevents abuse by repeated adjournments; policy against uncertainty in execution sales.

holdings.text: O. XXXIV r. 5 and O. XXI r. 92 must be interpreted harmoniously: deposit permitted before confirmation, but sale must be confirmed under r.92(1) unless deposit made prior thereto.

anchor.surface_text: We have to interpret O. XXXIV r. 5 and O. XXI r. 92 harmoniously and on a harmonious interpretation of the two provisions it is clear that though the mortgagor has the right to deposit the. amount due at any time before companyfirmation of sale, there is numberquestion of his being granted time under O. XXXIV r. 5 and if the provisions of O. XXI r. 92 1 apply the sale must be companyfirmed unless before the companyfirmation the mortgagor judg- ment-debtor has deposited the amount as permitted by O. XXXIV r. 5.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonious construction reconciles deposit right with mandatory confirmation; no implied extension power.

holdings.text: Once conditions of O. XXI r. 92(1) are satisfied, executing court must confirm the sale.

anchor.surface_text: We may in this companynection refer to the decision of this Court in Janak Rai v. Gurdial Singh, where it has been laid down that once the companyditions of O. XXI r. 92 (1) are companyplied with, the executing companyrt must companyfirm the sale.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows Supreme Court precedent in Janak Rai v. Gurdial Singh binding on point.

holdings.text: The time till November 21, 1958 was granted by consent of parties as part of oral compromise for withdrawal of O. XXI r. 90 application.

anchor.surface_text: It is obvious from the order-sheet of October 7, 1958 that an oral companypromise was arrived at between the parties in companyrt on that day. By that companypromise time was granted to the respondents to deposit the entire amount due to the decree-holder and the auction-purchaser by November 21, 1958. Obviously the basis of the companypromise was that the respondents withdrew their application under O. XXI r. 90 while the decree-holder society and the auction-purchaser appellant agreed that time might be given to deposit the amount up to November 21, 1958.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Order-sheet evidence shows exchange: withdrawal for time grant; same judge later noted consent; oral compromise valid.

holdings.text: O. XXXIV r. 5 applies to execution of Registrar's order treated as mortgage decree (assumed for decision).

anchor.surface_text: We shall proceed on that assumption that O. XXXIV c. 5 applies in the present case and that the order of the Registrar which was under execution was a final decree in a mortgage suit.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Proceeds on assumption without deciding applicability, as outcome same either way.

anchor.surface_text: Janak Rai v. Gurdial Singh 1 , where it has been laid down that once the conditions of O. XXI r. 92 1 are complied with, the executing companyrt must companyfirm the sale. It is on these principles that we have to decide whether the trial companyrt was companyrect. We have already indicated that the sale was held on April 7, 1958, and in the numbermal companyrse it would have been companyfirmed after 30 days unless an application under r. 89, r. 90, or r. 91 of O. XXI was made.

anchor.surface_text: The observation of the District Judge that the companyrt has always the power to postpone passing orders companyfirming sale of immovable property is in our view incorrect, in the face of the provisions companytained in O. XXI r. 92 (1). It is obvious from the order-sheet of October 7, 1958 that an oral companypromise was arrived at between the parties in companyrt on that day. By that companypromise time was granted to the respondents to deposit the entire amount due to the decree-holder and the auction-purchaser by November 21, 1958. Obviously the basis of the companypromise was that the respondents withdrew their application under O. XXI r. 90 while the decree-holder society and the auction-purchaser appellant agreed that time might be given to deposit the amount up to November 21, 1958.
